references: Moler, P.E. and J. Kezer. 1993. Karyology and systematics of the salamander genus Pseudobranchus (Sirenidae). Copeia 1993:39-47.
Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.

Moler, P.E. 2005. Pseudobranchus axanthus (Netting and Goin 1942), Southern Dwarf Siren. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 908-909.

habitat_description: The southern dwarf siren is an eel-like salamander endemic to peninsular Florida. Lacking hind limbs with only three-toed minute forelimbs, this species inhabits cypress ponds, swamps, ditches, marshes, limestone sinks, and other permanent and semi-permanent aquatic environments (Moler and Kezer 1993, Petranka 1998). They are often found amongst the roots of the introduced water hyacinth (Petranka 1998) and can be abundant in floating mats of vegetation and mucky shorelines (Moler 2005). They will also utilize open marsh and open prairie wetlands and appear to prefer less acidic habitats than P. striatus - the Northern Dwarf Siren (Wilson 1995).
